author: Evan Bartlett
title: Jose Mourinho reveals dressing room chat with Sir Alex Ferguson
text:
Jose Mourinho and Sir Alex Ferguson enjoy a friendly relationship (Picture: Getty Images) Jose Mourinho says he has urged Sir Alex Ferguson to spend more time in the Manchester United dressing room.
The former manager, who won 38 trophies in his 26 years at Old Trafford, has avoided interfering in first-team matters since retiring in 2013.
While Sir Alex, now a director and club ambassador, still attends most games, he has been speaking with players more since Mourinho took charge.
Neymar drops transfer bombshell when naming the FOUR Premier League clubs he admires ‘At the end of games, when he, Sir Bobby Charlton and the CEO come down and he’s the only one that doesn’t come in the changing rooms, I told him this type of situation makes no sense, he needs to feel free to do what a person of his stature that represents the club can do,’ Mourinho told Portuguese television channel SIC.
The current manager explained he has a good relationship with his illustrious predecessor and clearly holds Sir Alex in high regard.
Sir Alex Ferguson is United’s longest serving manager, winning 38 trophies in his 36 years at the club (Picture: Getty Images) However, Mourinho added, he found it strange that Sir Alex kept his distance from the squad.
‘We have the same friendship we always have had, an SMS, a birthday or Christmas card.
‘He wanted to leave and not return, maybe for his own comfort. I told him, it made no sense, us travelling to London on a private train and Sir Alex, going by car.’
Mourinho says the club’s longest serving manager now travels with the team to away games.
”No, you come in the train’,’ Mourinho said he told Sir Alex.
Sir Alex kept his distance from the dressing room when David Moyes and Louis van Gaal were in charge (Picture: Getty Images) ‘He’s so respectful that he got a bit shy in this approach; it has to be us to make him feel cared for, and made him feel that in our heads there aren’t ghosts.’
Back in December, Mourinho also revealed that he invited Sir Alex to attend training at the club’s Carrington complex.
‘I’m the type of person who does not see ghosts,’ Mourinho said at the time.

‘I respect the past and I know he loves the club.
‘We have good relations and I know this is his house.
‘When he wants to come here, to the dressing room, to see the players train, he knows he is more than welcome.’
The new approach certainly seems to be working. United are now unbeaten in 18 league games – their best run since Sir Alex stepped down – and have climbed up to fifth in the table.
